questions.text: A young boy was brought to the casualty with a history of fever and acute right lower abdominal pain. On examination, he was febrile and his pulse rate was 106 beats/min. Tenderness was felt in right iliac fossa. The CT scan image is shown below. Which of the following signs will not be seen in this disease? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ballance sign

 

The patient's history and CT findings are indicative of acute appendicitis. Ballance sign is not seen in acute appendicitis.

 

Ballance's sign is seen in splenic trauma, where dullness is seen on right flank on percussion, which doesn’t shift on lateral position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. McBurney's tenderness: Deep tenderness at McBurney's point, known as McBurney's sign, is a sign of acute appendicitis. McBurney's point is a point at one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine and umbilicus.

 

Option B. Rovsing sign: Rovsing sign is seen in appendicitis. Deep palpation of the left iliac fossa causes pain in the right iliac fossa.

 

Option C. Psoas sign: Psoas sign is seen in appendicitis. Sometimes, the inflamed appendix lies on the psoas muscle, and the patient, often a young adult, will lie with the right hip flexed, for pain relief.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Findings on CT that are suggestive of acute appendicitis include:

 

  • Appendiceal dilatation (>6 mm in diameter)
  • Appendiceal wall thickening (>3 mm) and enhancement

questions.text: A 37-year-old male patient presents to the surgical emergency with a history of peptic ulcer disease and pain in abdomen, bloating, and obstipation for 3 days. What is the next line in management? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Given scenario of history of peptic ulcer disease with acute abdomen suggests a peptic ulcer perforation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV fluids: Administering intravenous (IV) fluids is essential to address potential dehydration or peritonitis, to stabilise the patient.

 

Option B. CECT abdomen (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the abdomen): Performing a CECT abdomen is a diagnostic step that can help identify the cause of the patient's symptoms, such as complications related to peptic ulcer disease, including perforation or other abdominal pathologies.

 

Option C. Exploratory laparotomy: An exploratory laparotomy may be necessary if the patient's condition deteriorates or if there are signs of a surgical emergency, such as peritonitis or suspected perforation.

 

In summary, option D is correct because it covers the initial steps in managing this patient comprehensively, including addressing fluid balance (IV fluids), diagnostic imaging (CECT abdomen), and considering surgical intervention (exploratory laparotomy) if indicated by the clinical presentation and imaging findings

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perforation of a hollow viscus is a life-threatening condition caused by the rupture of the alimentary tract.
  • This results in the leakage of enteric contents, leading to acute bacterial peritonitis.
  • Clinical features include abdominal pain and distension, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, rebound tenderness, decreased or absent bowel sounds, and guarding on palpation.
  • Investigations include estimating the white blood cell count, urea, serum electrolytes, and an erect abdominal radiograph showing free gas under the diaphragm.
  • CECT is the most sensitive investigation to detect minimal/suspected pneumoperitoneum.
  • Management includes IV fluids and exploratory laparotomy.

choices.text: Rough handling of thyroid during surgery

questions.text: Which of the following is the usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inadequate patient preparation

 

Inadequate preparation of a patient with hyperthyroidism before thyroidectomy, such as not optimizing thyroid function and medication management, can increase the risk of thyroid storm. Proper preoperative management and stabilization of thyroid function are crucial to prevent this complication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rough handling of thyroid during surgery: While rough handling during thyroid surgery can potentially lead to complications, it is not the usual cause of thyroid storm.

 

Option B. Due to parathyroid gland injury: The parathyroid glands are separate from the thyroid gland and regulate calcium levels in the body. Complications involving the parathyroid glands can occur during thyroid surgery leading to postoperative hypocalcemia.

 

Option D. Infections: Infections can occur as complications after thyroid surgery, but they are not the usual cause of thyroid storm. Thyroid storm is primarily related to the excessive release of thyroid hormones into the bloodstream.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A thyroid storm, also known as thyrotoxic crisis, is a rare but life-threatening medical emergency that occurs in individuals with severe hyperthyroidism. Hyperthyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland produces an excessive amount of thyroid hormones, primarily thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3). In a thyroid storm, these hormone levels become dangerously elevated, leading to a wide range of symptoms and complications.

 

Symptoms of a thyroid storm may include:

 

  1. High fever
  2. Rapid and irregular heartbeat (tachycardia)
  3. Elevated blood pressure
  4. Extreme agitation and restlessness
  5. Profuse sweating
  6. Tremors and shaking
  7. Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea
  8. Delirium or confusion
  9. Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
  10. Coma (in severe cases)

 

Thyroid storms can be triggered by various factors, such as surgery, infection, trauma, or medication changes in individuals with underlying hyperthyroidism. The condition is more common in people with Graves' disease, a common cause of hyperthyroidism.

 

Treatment of a thyroid storm is a medical emergency and typically involves a combination of interventions to rapidly lower thyroid hormone levels, control symptoms, and support vital organ function.

 

The usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy is inadequate patient preparation before surgery. Thus, patient preparation pre-operatively involves ensuring a euthyroid state.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the otolaryngology clinic with complaints of pain and swelling in the right side of his face. Upon examination, the physician noted swelling in the parotid gland, which is located in the cheek area. The patient also reported that his symptoms worsened when he ate food, and he had lost his appetite due to the discomfort. The physician ordered an ultrasound imaging of the salivary glands, which revealed the presence of multiple hyper-echoic areas within the parotid gland. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sialolithiasis

 

  • Sialolithiasis is a condition where a stone or calculus forms within a salivary gland or duct.
  • This condition is most commonly found in the submandibular gland but can also occur in the parotid gland and other salivary glands.
  • Sialolithiasis can cause symptoms such as pain, swelling, and tenderness in the affected gland, difficulty opening the mouth, and dry mouth, especially during eating when salivary secretion increases (known as Meal time syndrome).
  • The stones themselves can sometimes be palpated and can be seen on imaging studies like ultrasound, which might display hyper-echoic (darker) areas representing the stones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foreign body: A foreign body in the context of the parotid gland could refer to any external object that has somehow made its way into the gland or its duct. It's an uncommon occurrence for a foreign body to be located in the salivary glands. Typically, if someone were to suspect a foreign body, there would likely be a history of trauma or an incident where the foreign object could have entered the gland.

 

Option C. Osteoma of the floor of the mouth: Osteoma is a benign bone tumor. An osteoma of the floor of the mouth would represent an abnormal growth of bone within that specific region. It wouldn't typically be a cause of parotid gland swelling or discomfort. Moreover, osteomas are more radiopaque and wouldn't typically present as hyper-echoic areas on an ultrasound.

 

Option D. Cervical lymphadenopathy: Cervical lymphadenopathy refers to the enlargement of lymph nodes in the cervical (neck) region. Enlarged lymph nodes can be due to various causes, including infections, inflammatory conditions, or malignancies. While they can be present near the parotid gland, they are distinct from it. Swelling of the lymph nodes wouldn't typically cause pain that worsens during eating, as described in the patient's symptoms.

 

Given the symptoms described, especially the pain that worsens with eating, and the ultrasound findings, Sialolithiasis (option A) is the most likely diagnosis for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sialolithiasis, characterized by the formation of calculi in the salivary glands, typically presents with pain and swelling, especially during meals.
  • Ultrasound imaging can identify hyper-echoic areas representing the stones, helping in the diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the ER following a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient opens his eyes to a painful stimulus, speaks inappropriately, and withdraws his limbs to a painful stimulus. What is his GCS score? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) E2V3M4

 

The GCS score of this patient is E2V3M4

 

  • Opening eves to a painful stimulus - E2
  • Speak inappropriately - V3
  • Withdraws his limbs to a painful stimulus - M4

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is an essential tool for assessing the level of consciousness in patients with traumatic brain injury.
  • It involves evaluating the eye opening response, verbal response, and motor response, with scores ranging from 3 (deep coma) to 15 (fully awake).
  •  Understanding how to correctly assess and calculate the GCS score is crucial for determining the severity of the injury and guiding appropriate medical intervention.

questions.text: After a fall from a height, a 10-year-old child presented to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain. Upon examination, the child's vital signs were stable, but tenderness was noted in the left lumbar region. What would be the best investigation of choice? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contrast enhanced CT scan

 

  • The given clinical vignette with abdominal pain and tenderness in the left lumbar region following a fall is suggestive of blunt renal trauma.
  • Radiological investigations are indicated when there is gross hematuria, shock in combination with microscopic hematuria, pediatric renal trauma, and penetrating injuries.
  • A CECT is the investigation of choice for blunt renal trauma in a hemodynamically stable patient.
  • Contrast enhanced CT scan (CECT):  Correct. In cases of trauma, especially from a fall, a CECT scan provides detailed imaging of the abdomen, allowing the visualization of internal organs, blood vessels, and tissues. When there's a suspicion of renal trauma due to tenderness in the left lumbar region (location of the kidney), CECT can identify the presence and extent of the injury. In a hemodynamically stable patient (as indicated by the child's stable vital signs), CECT is the preferred diagnostic modality for blunt renal trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retrograde urethrogram: This is a radiographic study of the posterior urethra using a contrast agent. It's primarily used when there's a suspicion of urethral injury, typically indicated by symptoms like blood at the urethral meatus or an inability to urinate.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: This approach implies observation without immediate intervention or imaging. While "wait and watch" can be appropriate in some cases, the potential seriousness of blunt renal trauma (especially in a child) warrants a more proactive approach to accurately diagnose and manage the injury.

 

Option D. Emergency laparotomy: It's indicated in situations where there's significant internal injury, and immediate surgical intervention is required. While it's a possibility in cases of trauma, the child's stable vital signs suggest a more conservative diagnostic approach, like a CECT scan, should be performed first to determine the extent of injury before jumping to surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of suspected blunt renal trauma, particularly in a hemodynamically stable patient, a contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice.
  • This allows for detailed imaging of the abdomen to accurately diagnose and assess the extent of the injury.

questions.text: Which investigation is not necessary for the following condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 24-h pH monitoring

 

24-hr pH monitoring is done in GERD. The above image is suggestive of gradual narrowing in lower esophagus, likely to be achalasia.

 

This is a test that measures the pH of the esophagus over a 24-hour period to assess for abnormal acid reflux. While not typically necessary for the diagnosis of achalasia cardia, 24-hour pH monitoring may be used to rule out gastroesophageal reflux disease as a potential cause of dysphagia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timed barium study: In the case of achalasia cardia, the barium will be retained in the esophagus for more than five minutes and the study may reveal a dilated esophagus with a 'bird's beak' appearance at the gastroesophageal junction.

 

Option B. Endoscopy: Endoscopy may be used to rule out other potential causes of dysphagia, such as esophageal cancer, and to obtain biopsy samples if needed.

 

Option C. Esophageal manometry: This is a diagnostic test that measures the pressure and motility of the esophagus during swallowing. In the case of achalasia cardia, esophageal manometry may reveal incomplete relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter in response to swallowing, high resting LES pressure, and absent esophageal peristalsis. It is the test of choice for diagnosis of achalasia.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the treatment of a patient who presented with the following as shown in the image? Earlier the abdominal mass was reducible, but now it has become irreducible. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Umbilical excision with herniorrhaphy

 

The clinical scenario presented is that of an umbilical hernia that was previously reducible but has now become irreducible. This suggests the hernia has become complicated, possibly due to incarceration or strangulation, where the contents are trapped, leading to ischemia or gangrene of the herniated tissue. The overlying skin also appears gangrenous and requires excision.

 

The correct management involves surgical intervention to excise the affected umbilical tissue and perform herniorrhaphy, which is a repair of the hernia without the use of a mesh, particularly when there are complications such as strangulation or infection. The surgical approach must address both the excision of compromised tissue and the closure of the hernial defect to prevent recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Umbilical excision: This option only addresses the excision of the skin and does not treat the underlying hernia. Simply excising the umbilical tissue will not resolve the hernia defect or prevent recurrence, making this option inadequate.

 

Option C. Antibiotics: Antibiotics alone are not a definitive treatment for a hernia. While antibiotics may be used if there is an associated infection, they do not resolve the underlying mechanical problem of a hernia.

 

Option D. Incision and drainage: This procedure is appropriate for abscesses and localized infections but not for hernias. There is no indication of an abscess in this scenario; rather, it is a hernia with possible ischemic or gangrenous changes, requiring surgical repair rather than drainage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of complicated umbilical hernias, especially when the hernia becomes irreducible, surgical intervention with umbilical excision and herniorrhaphy is necessary to repair the hernia and prevent further complications.

choices.text: Small frequent meals, increase protein content
Reverse Bilroth II to Bilroth I/Roux-en-Y

questions.text: What is the initial management for a patient who presents with diarrhea within 15 minutes of meals, after having undergone a Bilroth II gastrectomy? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Small frequent meals, increase protein content

 

 

The patient has undergone a Bilroth II gastrectomy, which involves a distal gastrectomy with a gastrojejunal anastomosis.

 

This surgical procedure can lead to a condition known as dumping syndrome. Dumping syndrome occurs when food, especially sugar, moves from the stomach into the small intestine too quickly.

 

There are two types of dumping syndrome:

 

  • Early dumping syndrome: Occurs within 5 to 20 minutes after eating. Symptoms include diarrhea, bloating, dizziness, and tachycardia.
  • Late dumping syndrome: Occurs 1 to 3 hours after eating. Symptoms are similar but occur later.

 

The initial management of dumping syndrome, whether early or late, involves dietary modifications:

 

  • Small, frequent meals.
  • Increased protein content to stabilize blood sugar levels.
  • Avoidance of high glycemic index foods such as milkshakes, sodas, and refined flour products.
  • Avoidance of very liquid meals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reverse Bilroth II to Bilroth I/Roux-en-Y: This is incorrect as a first-line management as it involves another surgical procedure.

 

Option C. Insulin: This is incorrect as insulin is used for blood sugar management in diabetes, not for dumping syndrome.

 

Option D. Symptomatic Rx: This does not specify any dietary modifications required to manage dumping syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial management of dumping syndrome after a Bilroth II gastrectomy is dietary modification, specifically small frequent meals with increased protein content and avoiding high glycemic index foods.

questions.text: Decubitus ulcer is best classified as: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Pressure ulcer

 

Explanation:

 

Decubitus ulcer is synonymous with pressure ulcer. These terms describe tissue necrosis with ulceration resulting from prolonged pressure that exceeds capillary occlusion pressure (over 30mmHg), leading to tissue anoxia and breakdown. They occur in areas where bony prominences create sustained pressure against soft tissues, particularly in bedridden or immobile patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venous ulcer - Venous ulcers have distinct characteristics, typically appearing above the medial malleolus in the "Gaiter's area." They present as shallow ulcers associated with other signs of venous insufficiency such as hyperpigmentation, dermatitis, and varicosities. Unlike decubitus ulcers, they result from venous hypertension rather than direct pressure.

 

Option B. Arterial ulcer - Arterial (ischemic) ulcers occur at distal locations like toes and dorsum of foot. They are characteristically deep, severely painful, and associated with signs of peripheral vascular disease including brittle nails, sparse hair, and intermittent claudication. They stem from inadequate arterial perfusion rather than external pressure.

 

Option C. Neuropathic ulcer - Neuropathic ulcers typically form on weight-bearing areas of the foot with characteristic "punched out" edges and surrounding callosity. They develop due to sensory, motor, and autonomic neuropathy (commonly in diabetic patients) rather than from external pressure. The painless nature of these ulcers distinguishes them from decubitus ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pressure sores (decubitus ulcers) result from sustained pressure exceeding tissue perfusion pressure, causing ischemia and necrosis predominantly at bony prominences like the ischium, greater trochanter, and sacrum in immobile patients.

questions.text: Sequence of color change in Raynaud’s disease:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) White - Blue - Red

 

Explanation:

 

Raynaud’s disease, also known as Raynaud’s phenomenon, is characterized by a triphasic color change in the digits, typically triggered by cold exposure or emotional stress. The sequence of color change follows these stages:

 

  1. White (Stage of Local Syncope): Initially, exposure to cold or stress causes digital arterioles to spasm, reducing blood flow. This leads to blanching or pallor in the affected digits.
  2. Blue (Stage of Local Asphyxia): As the spasm persists, capillaries and venules dilate in response to ischemic metabolites, resulting in cyanosis or a bluish discoloration due to deoxygenated blood.
  3. Red (Stage of Recovery): Upon rewarming or resolution of the vasospasm, there is a sudden increase in blood flow through the dilated arteries and capillaries, causing reactive hyperemia and a bright red color in the digits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Red - Blue - White: Incorrect sequence; does not represent Raynaud's color change pattern.

 

Option C. White - Red - Blue: Incorrect sequence; does not represent Raynaud's color change pattern.

 

Option D. Red - White - Blue: Incorrect sequence; does not represent Raynaud's color change pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequence of color change in Raynaud’s disease is White (pallor) - Blue (cyanosis) - Red (hyperemia).

questions.text: Size cut off for operating an abdominal aortic aneurysm is greater than? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5.5 cm

 

(5.5) The threshold for surgical repair of an AAA is commonly set at 5.5 cm in diameter. This means that when the AAA reaches or exceeds 5.5 cm in size, surgical intervention is usually recommended to prevent the risk of rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AAA refers to an enlargement or ballooning of the abdominal aorta. It can be a potentially life-threatening condition if it ruptures.

 

The size of the AAA is a crucial factor in determining the need for surgical intervention. The risk of rupture increases significantly as the size of the aneurysm grows.

 

An asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm in an otherwise fit patient is considered for repair if >55 mm in diameter (measured by ultrasonography). The annual incidence of rupture rises from 1% or less in aneurysms that are <55 mm in diameter to a significant level of nearly 25%, in those that are 70 mm in diameter.

 

As open elective surgery (transabdominal) carries a 5% mortality rate, the balance is in favor of elective operation once the maximum diameter is >55 mm.

 

6 monthly follow-up ultrasonographic surveillance is indicated for asymptomatic aneurysms <55 mm in diameter.

choices.text: Strap his thorax, abdomen and lower limbs on a stretcher
Put patient on lateral position and shift him immediately
Roll the patient and put on a hard board

questions.text: All of the following are done to transport a polytrauma patient who is conscious except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Put patient on lateral position and shift him immediately

 

This option is not a standard practice when transporting conscious polytrauma patients. Shifting a conscious patient to a lateral position and immediately moving them can risk further injury and discomfort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strap his thorax, abdomen, and lower limbs on a stretcher: This is a common and necessary practice when transporting a conscious polytrauma patient. It helps secure the patient to the stretcher to prevent movement and further injury during transport.

 

Option B. Apply a cervical collar: This is done to immobilize the cervical spine, till a cervical injury is ruled out.

 

Option D. Roll the patient and put on a hardboard: Rolling a conscious polytrauma patient and placing them on a hardboard (spinal board) can be a part of the standard protocol for immobilizing the spine and minimizing movement during transport. This is done to prevent potential spinal cord injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with polytrauma are shifted in supine or prone position (not in lateral position) by laying them over a firm surface, in order to restrict the spinal movement.

 

As per ATLS guidelines, in patients with trauma, airway management is first done along with cervical spine stabilization. All trauma patients unless proven otherwise are considered to have an injured vertebral column.

 

The patient is placed supine on a firm surface without rotating or bending the spinal column and a rigid cervical collar (Philadelphia collar) is applied.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is not performed via the perineal approach in a patient with rectal prolapse? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ripstein operation

 

This procedure is designed to treat rectal prolapse. It involves fixing the rectum to the sacrum using a synthetic mesh. This procedure is performed via an abdominal approach and not through the perineum. Hence, the answer to the question is A) Ripstein operation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiersch operation: The Thiersch operation is a perineal procedure. It involves placing a wire or other synthetic material around the anus to encircle and narrow it. This provides support to the anal canal and rectum, helping to prevent or treat rectal prolapse.

 

Option C. Altemeier procedure: Also known as the perineal rectal resection, the Altemeier procedure is a surgical treatment for rectal prolapse. During this operation, the prolapsed portion of the rectum is resected, and the remaining rectum is sutured back to the anal canal. This procedure is performed through the perineal approach.

 

Option D. Delorme operation: The Delorme operation is a perineal approach to treat rectal prolapse. The mucosa and submucosa of the prolapsed rectum are excised, and the muscularis is plicated. The remaining mucosa is then sutured back. This procedure is typically reserved for older patients or those who are not candidates for a more invasive abdominal procedure.

choices.text: Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy

questions.text: An octogenarian female comes to your clinic reporting feelings of constant fatigue. Upon performing imaging studies, you discover that she has a scleroatrophic gallbladder containing impacted stones. In addition, a sizable stone is detected within the common bile duct, causing dilation of the biliary tree. What should be the subsequent course of action in her treatment? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

 

Explanation:

 

Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure that allows for the visualization and management of bile duct stones. It is particularly useful when there is a stone in the common bile duct (CBD). ERCP can be used to remove or extract stones from the common bile duct and may also involve the placement of a stent to relieve biliary obstruction if necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy: Cholecystectomy (removal of the gallbladder) may be considered as a subsequent procedure, but it is usually not the initial step in patients with impacted stones in the gallbladder and CBD stones. ERCP is performed first to address the CBD stone and relieve any associated biliary obstruction.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: Waiting and watching may not be appropriate in this case because the patient is symptomatic with constant fatigue, which can be related to biliary obstruction. Immediate intervention is necessary to relieve the obstruction and prevent complications.

 

Option D. CT scan: A CT scan may have been done as part of the initial imaging studies to assess the condition, but it is not the definitive treatment for gallbladder and CBD stones. The primary treatment should focus on relieving the obstruction caused by the CBD stone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the preferred initial treatment for patients with common bile duct stones and biliary obstruction, as it allows for both diagnosis and therapeutic intervention, such as stone removal and stent placement.

questions.text: Apart from the abdomen, which body part is included in e-FAST? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thoracic cavity

 

eFAST or extended FAST covers 4 regions of abdomen (epigastrium, right and left paracolic areas and pelvis) and both the thoracic spaces.

 

Correct. The e-FAST exam extends the basic FAST exam by including views of the thoracic cavity, specifically looking for evidence of pneumothorax or hemothorax. This is done by assessing the pleural spaces on both sides of the chest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retroperitoneum: These injuries are often missed on e-FAST.

 

Option B. Peripheral vessels: Peripheral vessels are not the primary focus of the e-FAST exam. The main goal of e-FAST is to rapidly identify free fluid in specific body cavities that might indicate trauma.

 

Option D. Dural and subdural spaces: These spaces are within the cranial cavity and pertain to the brain. They are not part of the e-FAST exam.

 

In summary, the e-FAST exam primarily evaluates the abdomen for evidence of trauma, but it also extends to the thoracic cavity to look for signs of pneumothorax or hemothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

E-FAST stands for Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma, which is a bedside ultrasound examination used to evaluate trauma patients. It involves the use of a portable ultrasound machine to assess for free fluid in the abdomen, chest, and around the heart.

 

 

In addition to identifying free fluid, e-FAST can also be used to evaluate for other injuries, such as pneumothorax, hemothorax, and pericardial effusion. E-FAST has become a standard of care in trauma evaluation and is a valuable tool in the early detection and treatment of life-threatening injuries.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male underwent a bilateral laparoscopic hernia repair for inguinal hernia. Postoperatively, he complained of pain in the right thigh. Which of the following nerve entrapment leads to this symptom? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

 

  • Pain in the thigh (Meralgia Paraesthetica) is due to entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. This nerve entrapment often occurs during laparoscopic hernia repair, especially during the placement of mesh.
  •  The nerves commonly injured in laparoscopic repair are the genitofemoral and lateral femoral cutaneous nerves of the thigh.
  •  Patients with lateral cutaneous nerve injury present with acute neuropathic pain along the dermatomal distribution, resulting in meralgia paresthetica.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Treatment consists of rest, ice, NSAIDs, physical therapy, and possible local corticosteroid and anesthetic injection.
  • Drugs like gabapentin can be used to manage neuropathic pain.
  • In laparoscopic transabdominal preperitoneal (TAPP) repair, to reduce the chances of nerve injury during mesh placement, tacks are ideally placed above the iliopubic tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ilioinguinal nerve: The ilioinguinal nerve leads to sensory disturbances and pain over the skin of the genitalia and upper medial thigh. This nerve is most commonly injured in open repair of inguinal hernia, not laparoscopic repair.

 

Option B. Iliohypogastric nerve: The iliohypogastric nerve leads to pain in the inguinal and suprapubic regions. Injury to this nerve does not typically result in pain isolated to the thigh.

 

Option C. Femoral nerve: Femoral nerve injury presents as lower limb numbness, weakness, tingling, paralysis, or pain along the nerve. However, femoral nerve injury is less likely to be caused by laparoscopic hernia repair and more often associated with other surgical procedures or traumatic events.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meralgia paresthetica, characterized by pain in the thigh, is commonly due to entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, especially following laparoscopic hernia repair.
  •  Proper placement of mesh and tacks during surgery is crucial to avoid this nerve injury.

questions.text: Mr. Seth recently underwent surgery to remove a parathyroid gland due to hyperparathyroidism. The surgeon informed the patient that one or more of the parathyroid glands may be transferred to another location during the surgery to protect them or due to their location. The parathyroid is commonly transferred to? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Brachioradialis

 

Explanation:

 

The most common site for the relocation of the parathyroid gland(s) is in the forearm muscle, specifically the nondominant side brachioradialis. Transplantation to this location provides several advantages:

  • Accessibility: The forearm location is easily accessible for potential future surgical interventions if necessary.
  • Monitoring: This location allows for straightforward monitoring of parathyroid function using simple clinical tests.
  • Functionality: The transplanted gland(s) will continue to produce parathyroid hormone normally, aiding in the regulation of calcium levels in the body.
  • Ease of Removal: If there is disease recurrence after surgery, the forearm location facilitates easy removal.
  • Typically, a total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted in a type of heterotopic transplant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triceps: Triceps is not a preferred site for parathyroid transplantation due to less accessibility and monitoring challenges compared to the brachioradialis.

 

Option B. Biceps: Biceps is also not commonly used for parathyroid transplantation because it does not offer the same ease of access and monitoring advantages as the brachioradialis.

 

Option C. Sartorius: Sartorius is not a preferred site for parathyroid transplantation. The forearm muscle (brachioradialis) is favored for its convenience and monitoring benefits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The brachioradialis muscle in the forearm is the most common site for parathyroid gland relocation during surgery due to its ease of access, convenient monitoring, and straightforward removal if needed.

questions.text: Identify the incision made and marked is the image: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gibson 

 

  • The Gibson incision is correct in this scenario, assuming the surgical mark and procedure are aimed at accessing structures in the lower quadrant of the abdomen or the pelvis. This incision provides the necessary exposure while minimizing damage to the muscular and nerve structures

 

This is a type of oblique incision made along the line of the inguinal ligament. It is primarily used for procedures involving the lower ureter, pelvic kidney, or bladder surgery. It provides excellent exposure to the lower abdomen and pelvic areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Robson Incision: This is also known as the "classic gridiron" incision. It's a muscle-splitting incision used primarily for accessing the appendix during an appendectomy. It runs obliquely in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.

 

Option B. Battle Incision: Less commonly referenced, this incision isn't widely recognized in standard surgical texts under this name. It may refer to a specialized or less commonly used approach.

 

Option D. Kocher Incision: This incision is typically used for biliary surgery. It is a subcostal incision made parallel to the costal margin, usually on the right side, to provide access to the gallbladder and biliary tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gibson Incision is a type of oblique incision made along the line of the inguinal ligament. It is primarily used for procedures involving the lower ureter, pelvic kidney, or bladder surgery

choices.text: Insert needle in appropriate intercostal space

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He has chest trauma, a respiratory rate of 40 breaths per minute, and a blood pressure of 90/50 mmHg. The patient is conscious but only able to speak in short phrases. On examination, there is hyperresonance on the affected side of the chest. What should be your next immediate step in managing this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Insert needle in appropriate intercostal space

 

The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability and hyper-resonance on the affected side is suggestive of tension pneumothorax.

 

The next immediate step of management is inserting a needle i.e. needle decompression in the appropriate intercostal space (ICS).

 

The presence of hyper-resonance on percussion and the patient's signs of respiratory distress suggest a potential tension pneumothorax. A tension pneumothorax occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space and compresses the lung, leading to severe respiratory compromise. Inserting a needle (needle decompression) in the appropriate intercostal space is a life-saving procedure to release the trapped air and relieve the pressure on the affected lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intubate: While maintaining a patient's airway is crucial in cases of respiratory distress, intubation is not the immediate next step in this case. The patient is conscious and speaking, indicating that they have a patent airway. The primary concern is addressing the chest trauma and potential tension pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Start intravenous fluids urgently: While providing intravenous fluids may be necessary, it is not the immediate priority in this case.

 

Option D. Take a chest X-ray: While a chest X-ray can provide valuable diagnostic information, it is not the immediate next step in a suspected tension pneumothorax. Clinical signs and symptoms, including chest percussion and the patient's condition, warrant immediate intervention to relieve the pressure on the lung.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of tension pneumothorax:

 

  • Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line
  • Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety
  • Note: According to ATLS 10th edition
  • In adults, needle thoracostomy or needle decompression location is changed to 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line from 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • However, In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location remains at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.

questions.text: A patient undergoes thyroid surgery, and their surgeon is aiming to minimize nerve injury during the procedure. Which of the following nerves is least likely to be injured during thyroid surgery? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Marginal mandibular nerve

 

The marginal mandibular nerve is located in the lower part of the face, near the mandible. It is not directly associated with thyroid surgery and is far less likely to be injured during the procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrent laryngeal nerve: The recurrent laryngeal nerve is one of the most critical nerves to be cautious of during thyroid surgery. It runs near or through the thyroid gland and is vulnerable to injury in region of Berry’s ligament.

 

Option B. Ansa cervicalis: The ansa cervicalis is a nerve loop formed by cervical spinal nerves. While it may be in the vicinity of thyroid surgery, it is less likely to be directly affected by the procedure compared to other nearby nerves like the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Option C. External laryngeal nerve: The external laryngeal nerve is also in the vicinity of thyroid surgery and is most commonly injured during thyroid surgery. Its main function is to supply the cricothyroid muscle.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The marginal mandibular nerve is the nerve least likely to be injured during thyroid surgery.
  • The nerve is high up, closer to the mandibular margin.
  • The ansa cervicalis may be injured if the strap muscles are not cut high enough during surgery.
  • The superior laryngeal nerve may be injured near the superior pole of the thyroid.
  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve may be injured if dissection is done below the cricoid cartilage or near the tracheoesophageal groove

questions.text: Mrs. Patel is a 45-year-old woman who has recently been diagnosed with estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. Her doctor informs her that the cancer is hormone-dependent. The doctor recommends a treatment plan that includes surgery, radiation therapy, and hormone therapy. What is the drug used for estrogen dependent breast cancer? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tamoxifen

 

Explanation:

 

Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used to treat hormone receptor-positive breast cancers, particularly in premenopausal women. It is effective for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer, which is hormone-dependent. Tamoxifen works by blocking the effects of estrogen in the breast tissue, thereby preventing cancer cells from growing and spreading.

  • Mechanism of Action: Tamoxifen competes with estrogen for binding to estrogen receptors in breast tissue. By blocking estrogen's effects, it inhibits the growth and proliferation of estrogen-dependent cancer cells.
  • Administration: Tamoxifen is taken orally, usually once a day for five years.
  • Side Effects: Common side effects include hot flashes, mood changes, vaginal dryness, and an increased risk of blood clots (DVT).

 

Uses of Tamoxifen:

  • Primary Prophylaxis: Used for the primary prophylaxis of breast cancer in high-risk women.
  • Risk Reduction: Reduces the risk of carcinoma in the contralateral breast.
  • Recurrence Prevention: Lowers the risk of recurrence of carcinoma in both ipsilateral and contralateral breasts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estrogen: Estrogen is not used as a treatment for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer because it would promote cancer cell growth. In fact, therapies aim to reduce or block estrogen to prevent cancer progression.

 

Option B. Clomiphene citrate: Clomiphene citrate is a medication used to induce ovulation in women with fertility issues. It is not used in the treatment of breast cancer.

 

Option D. Adriamycin (Doxorubicin): Adriamycin is a chemotherapy drug used to treat various types of cancer, including breast cancer. It works by interfering with the DNA in cancer cells, preventing them from dividing and growing. While effective in some cancer treatments, it is not specifically used for hormone therapy in estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamoxifen is the drug used for treating estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer by blocking the effects of estrogen on breast tissue, thereby preventing the growth and spread of hormone-dependent cancer cells.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman complains of fatigue, weight gain, and increased sensitivity to cold. On physical examination, she has noticeable swelling in her neck the histological image is shown below. Additionally, an ultrasound examination shows that her thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged and has an uneven texture. Which of the following conditions is most likely the cause of her symptoms? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hashimoto’s thyroiditis

 

The given findings are suggestive of diffuse goitre with clinical hypothyroidism, suggestive of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis.

 

Hashimoto's thyroiditis, also known as chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis, is an autoimmune disorder that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland. Patients often present with hypothyroidism symptoms, such as fatigue, weight gain, and cold sensitivity. As for the histological findings, Hashimoto's thyroiditis is characterized by:

 

  1. Lymphocytic infiltration with germinal centers.
  2. Follicular cell damage.
  3. Reduced colloid and increased fibrous tissue.
  4. Presence of Hurthle cells (or Askanazy cells) which are oxyphilic cells with a granular cytoplasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medullary carcinoma: Medullary thyroid carcinoma originates from parafollicular C cells in the thyroid gland. These cells produce calcitonin, and the carcinoma often increases levels of this hormone. The tumor can appear as a firm mass in the neck. Histologically, it contains nests or sheets of cells in an amyloid stroma. It doesn't show the typical lymphocytic infiltration seen in Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Clinical hypothyroidism is not a feature.

 

Option B. Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma: Rarely, the thyroid gland can be affected by primary thyroid lymphoma, which often arises in the setting of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. However, it would be differentiated by its histological appearance, with large numbers of lymphoid cells but lacking the characteristic features of Hashimoto's, such as Hurthle cells. Hypothyroidism is not a feature.

 

Option C. Grave's disease: Grave's disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. It is an autoimmune disorder where antibodies stimulate the thyroid gland, leading to overproduction of thyroid hormones. Symptoms might include weight loss, increased heart rate, tremors, and exophthalmos (bulging eyes). The histology of Grave's disease is characterized by tall, columnar epithelial cells and scalloped colloid, which is different from the described histological findings.

 

Educational Objective:


Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of the thyroid gland, leading to hypothyroidism with symptoms such as fatigue, weight gain, and increased sensitivity to cold.

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is a liver transplant possible in the case of secondary tumours? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ca testis

 

  • Liver transplantation for metastatic cancer is generally considered with extreme caution due to the high risk of recurrence and the limited availability of organs. However, certain exceptions exist based on the specific type of cancer and its overall prognosis and responsiveness to other treatments. Here's an analysis of the scenarios mentioned:

 

In rare cases, liver transplantation might be considered for metastatic testicular cancer if it is isolated to the liver and the primary cancer is under control. Testicular cancer tends to have a better overall prognosis compared to many other cancers due to its high responsiveness to chemotherapy. If the metastasis is limited and other treatments have been effective, liver transplantation could be a potential option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melanoma: Liver transplantation is not typically recommended for metastatic melanoma due to the aggressive nature of the disease and the likelihood of widespread metastasis. Melanoma is known to respond poorly to immunosuppression, which is a requisite part of post-transplant care.

 

Option B. Breast Cancer (Ca breast): Like melanoma, metastatic breast cancer is generally not considered suitable for liver transplantation. Breast cancer can metastasize to multiple organs, and the post-transplant immunosuppression regime can exacerbate the spread and recurrence of the cancer.

 

Option D. Active Renal Cell Carcinoma (Active RCC): RCC is typically resistant to both chemotherapy and radiation, and like melanoma and breast cancer, is generally not considered suitable for liver transplantation due to poor outcomes associated with the disease's aggressive nature and potential for widespread metastatic sites.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liver transplantation for metastatic cancer is rare and generally only considered under specific conditions. These conditions typically include the isolation of metastasis to the liver, good control of the primary cancer, and a lack of other effective treatment options. Each type of cancer must be evaluated on its own characteristics, including its responsiveness to treatment and overall prognosis.

questions.text: A patient has undergone laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Identify the structure as marked? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystic artery

 

The image provided shows an intraoperative view during a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, focusing on the Calot's triangle. This area is critical for identifying key anatomical structures to safely remove the gallbladder.

 

Calot's triangle is bordered by the cystic duct, the common hepatic duct, and the inferior border of the liver. The "critical view of safety" is a surgical technique used to clearly identify the cystic artery and the cystic duct before clipping and cutting them.

 

In the image, the marked structure is the inner one, closer to the liver. This inner structure is the cystic artery. The outer structure, which is away from the liver and entering the gallbladder, is the cystic duct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic duct: The cystic duct is the tube that connects the gallbladder to the common bile duct. In the image, it is the outer structure marked CD, which is not the structure marked by the arrow.

 

Option C. Right hepatic artery: This artery supplies blood to the right lobe of the liver and is not typically involved in the structures identified within Calot's triangle during a cholecystectomy.

 

Option D. Hepatic duct: The hepatic duct is part of the biliary duct system, joining with the cystic duct to form the common bile duct. It is not the structure marked in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, it is crucial to identify the cystic artery and the cystic duct within Calot's triangle to prevent injury to the biliary structures and ensure a safe surgical procedure.

questions.text: Identify the type of drain: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed

 

The image displays a Romovac drain placed after mastectomy, which is a closed-type drain. Drains are utilized at surgical sites to collect air or fluid buildup, promoting wound healing by preventing cavity formation. Drains can be prophylactic in elective surgeries and therapeutic in emergency surgeries, with open, semi-open, and closed types.

 

They carry out their actions through suction

 

  • Eg. Romovac drain, Jackson Pratt drain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open: They are based on the principle of gravity or capillary effect

 

  • Eg. Corrugated drain, Foley’s catheter etc.\

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Romovac drain is a closed negative suction drain placed in subcutaneous tissue and indicated in modified radical mastectomy, subcutaneous swelling excision, and amputations. Other specialized drains include chest drains for air removal from the pleural cavity and T-tubes for bile drainage after surgical exploration of the bile duct.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male arrives at the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. The patient's vital signs are stable, and a focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) is ordered. Which condition is least likely to be diagnosed using FAST? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retroperitoneal hematoma

 

Detecting retroperitoneal hematoma is challenging with FAST because it is located deep within the abdominal cavity, behind the peritoneum. FAST primarily focuses on the pericardium, pleura, and peritoneum, making it less suitable for detecting retroperitoneal injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pericardial Effusion: FAST is effective at detecting pericardial effusions. It involves examining the pericardial sac for fluid accumulation with probe placed in epigastrium.

 

Option B. Pneumothorax: eFAST can detect pneumothorax to some extent by visualizing the pleural space for the presence of air.

 

Option D. Renal Injury: FAST can detect renal injuries by examining the perinephric space for signs of bleeding or fluid accumulation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Among the given options, FAST is the least effective in diagnosing retroperitoneal hematoma due to poor sensitivity of ultrasound for detecting it.
  • CT scan is the preferred diagnostic tool for retroperitoneal injuries, but it should only be performed on hemodynamically stable patients.
  • FAST stands for Focussed Assessment with Sonography for Trauma and is a non-invasive, rapid bedside test used to detect free fluid in the abdomen using sonography.
  • The patient is positioned supine, and a 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer is used to scan the subxiphoid, right and left upper quadrants, and suprapubic region to assess potential thoracoabdominal injuries.
  • eFAST is an extended version of FAST that incorporates left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and hemothorax.

questions.text: Which of the following bariatric procedures has shown to offer maximum weight reduction? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch (BPD/DS)

 

Explanation:

 

Biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch (BPD/DS) is a bariatric procedure that combines restrictive and malabsorptive techniques. It has been shown to provide the highest percentage of excess weight loss compared to other bariatric procedures. BPD/DS achieves significant weight reduction by reducing the stomach size and bypassing a substantial portion of the small intestine, which limits calorie absorption. However, this procedure also has a higher risk of nutritional complications compared to other bariatric surgeries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding: This procedure involves placing an adjustable band around the upper part of the stomach to restrict food intake. It results in less weight loss compared to BPD/DS.

 

Option C. Roux-en-Y Gastric bypass: This procedure is both restrictive and malabsorptive but results in less weight loss compared to BPD/DS.

 

Option D. Sleeve gastrectomy: This procedure involves removing a portion of the stomach to create a sleeve-like structure. While effective, it results in less weight loss compared to BPD/DS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch (BPD/DS) offers the maximum weight reduction among bariatric procedures but is associated with higher nutritional complications.

questions.text: Fr with respect to size of Foley's catheter refers to: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Outer Diameter

 

Fr, short for French, is a unit of measurement used for the outer diameter of a Foley catheter. It is a common way to denote the size of the catheter, especially in medical and healthcare settings. The French scale is based on a 3:1 ratio, where one French unit (Fr) is approximately equal to 0.33 millimeters in outer diameter. For example, a Foley catheter with a size of 16 Fr has an outer diameter of approximately 5.3 millimeters.

 

Therefore, the diameter of a catheter in millimeters can be determined by dividing the French size by 3.

questions.text: Which of the following pathology is shown in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hollow viscus perforation

 

The image provided shows a typical sign of free air under the right dome of the diaphragm. This finding is highly indicative of a hollow viscus perforation. When there is a perforation in any part of the gastrointestinal tract, air can escape into the peritoneal cavity. This air then rises to the highest point in the abdomen when the patient is in an upright position, which is under the diaphragm, and is visible on an upright chest X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subacute intestinal obstruction: This condition would not present with free air under the diaphragm. Instead, it would typically show dilated bowel loops with air-fluid levels on an abdominal X-ray.

 

Option B. Paralytic ileus: Paralytic ileus would also not present with free air under the diaphragm. It usually shows diffusely dilated bowel loops without a transition point on imaging studies.

 

Option C. Pleural effusion: A pleural effusion involves fluid accumulation in the pleural cavity and would not present with air under the diaphragm. It typically shows fluid in the pleural space on a chest X-ray, often blurring the costophrenic angle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of free air under the diaphragm on an upright chest X-ray is a classic radiographic finding indicative of a hollow viscus perforation. This is a critical sign that should prompt immediate medical evaluation and intervention.

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of waxing and waning jaundice in an alcoholic patient with dilatation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct on CT examination? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Periampullary carcinoma

 

The most probable diagnosis in this patient is periampullary carcinoma.

 

Here are the characteristic features of periampullary carcinoma:

 

  • Arises from the vicinity of the ampulla of Vater
  • Presents with jaundice that intermittently waxes and wanes due to partial relief of obstruction to bile ducts whenever the tumor undergoes necrosis and sloughing
  • Other symptoms include weight loss, pain, nausea, vomiting, pruritus, fever, and gastrointestinal bleeding
  • A three-phase CT scan is recommended for diagnosis- which shows double duct sign (dilated CBD and pancreatic duct).
  • Management includes resection, along with chemotherapy/chemoradiotherapy

 

Periampullary carcinoma refers to cancers that arise in the vicinity of the ampulla of Vater, where the bile duct and pancreatic duct converge before entering the duodenum. These tumors can obstruct both the common bile duct and pancreatic duct, leading to intermittent or waxing and waning jaundice. The anatomical location of periampullary carcinomas and double duct sign on CT makes them a likely cause in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cholangiocarcinoma: Cholangiocarcinoma is a cancer that originates in the bile ducts. While it can cause obstructive jaundice, it typically presents with a more gradual and progressive course of symptoms. It may cause dilatation of the bile ducts, but waxing and waning jaundice is less characteristic of cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Common bile duct stone: While a common bile duct stone can cause obstructive jaundice, it typically leads to a more acute presentation with sudden onset of symptoms. Waxing and waning jaundice is not a common feature of common bile duct stones.

 

Option D. Head of pancreas carcinoma: Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas, also known as pancreatic head carcinoma, can obstruct the common bile duct and cause jaundice. However, it tends to present with a more persistent and progressive form of jaundice rather than waxing and waning symptoms, as described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Periampullary carcinoma (option B) is the most likely cause of waxing and waning jaundice in an alcoholic patient with dilatation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct on CT examination due to its anatomical location and its potential to obstruct both ducts.

questions.text: Which of these is not a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hepatitis B infection

 

Cholangiocarcinoma, a type of cancer that forms in the bile ducts, has several well-established risk factors. These include chronic inflammatory conditions like primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), parasitic infections such as Opisthorchis viverrini, and congenital conditions like Caroli's disease. However, while Hepatitis C is recognized as a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma, Hepatitis B is not commonly associated with this type of cancer. The confusion often arises because Hepatitis B is a major risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma, another type of liver cancer, but not specifically for cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Caroli's disease: Caroli's disease is a congenital disorder characterized by the dilation of the bile ducts and is associated with an increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC): PSC is a chronic liver disease that causes inflammation and scarring of the bile ducts. It is a well-known risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option D. Opisthorchis V. (Opisthorchis viverrini): Opisthorchis viverrini, a liver fluke, is a parasitic infection known to increase the risk of cholangiocarcinoma, especially in endemic regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B infection is not a recognized risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma. Instead, focus on chronic inflammatory conditions, parasitic infections, and certain congenital disorders as key risk factors for this type of cancer.

questions.text: Out of the options given below the most common pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor (PNET) is: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insulinoma

 

Most common type of PNET seen is: Insulinoma

 

Insulinomas are the most common type of PNETs. They produce excess insulin, leading to hypoglycemia (low blood sugar) in affected individuals. Insulinomas are typically benign and occur more frequently than other types of PNETs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrinoma: Gastrinoma is a type of PNET that produces excess gastrin hormone. It is associated with a condition called Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Gastrinomas are relatively less common than insulinomas.

 

Option B. Somatostatinoma: Somatostatinomas are rare PNETs that produce excess somatostatin hormone. They can occur in the pancreas or other parts of the digestive system. They are less common than insulinomas.

 

Option D. VIPoma: VIPomas, also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome or pancreatic cholera, are PNETs that produce vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP). These tumors are relatively rare compared to insulinomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PNETs are a rare type of pancreatic tumor that originate from neuroendocrine cells in the pancreas.
  • PNETs are classified as either functioning or non-functioning based on their ability to produce hormones.
  • Diagnosis of PNETs typically involves imaging studies such as CT or MRI, as well as biopsy or blood tests to measure hormone levels.
  • Treatment options for PNETs may include surgery, chemotherapy, or radiation therapy, depending on the size, location, and type of tumor.

 

Insulinoma:

 

  • The investigation of choice for insulinoma 72-hour fasting glucose and serum insulin levels.
  • Medical management:
    • Octreotide
  • Surgical management - Enucleation

questions.text:
Which of these are included in extra-esophageal symptoms of GERD? (multiple correct combinations) (INICET MAY 2024)

 

a. Asthma
b. Laryngitis
c. Excessive phlegm
d. Pulmonary fibrosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is typically associated with symptoms such as heartburn, epigastric pain, and acid reflux. However, GERD can also present with a variety of extra-esophageal symptoms, which are manifestations outside the esophagus. These symptoms arise due to the aspiration of gastric contents or the stimulation of vagal reflexes.

 

  • Asthma: Nocturnal asthma can be triggered or exacerbated by GERD due to the reflux of stomach acid that can reach the airways, leading to bronchoconstriction.
  • Laryngitis: Laryngitis can occur when acid reflux irritates the laryngeal mucosa, leading to hoarseness or loss of voice.
  • Excessive phlegm: GERD can lead to chronic throat clearing and excessive phlegm production as the body attempts to clear the irritating reflux material from the throat.
  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Although less common, repeated aspiration of gastric contents can cause chronic inflammation in the lungs, leading to pulmonary fibrosis over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Since the  includes all options, there are no incorrect choices to explain in this instance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GERD can manifest not only with typical esophageal symptoms like heartburn but also with extra-esophageal symptoms such as asthma, laryngitis, excessive phlegm, and even pulmonary fibrosis.

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common histological subtype
Occult blood in stool is not seen

questions.text: Which of the following statements about gastric carcinoma are true:(NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Often associated with hypochlorhydria/achlorhydria

 

Explanation:

 

Gastric carcinoma, particularly adenocarcinoma, is often associated with conditions that lead to reduced gastric acidity, such as hypochlorhydria or achlorhydria. These conditions can result from chronic atrophic gastritis, pernicious anemia, and Helicobacter pylori infection, which are known risk factors for the development of gastric cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common histological subtype: Incorrect. The most common histological subtype of gastric carcinoma is adenocarcinoma, not squamous cell carcinoma.

 

Option C. Occult blood in stool is not seen: Incorrect. Occult blood in the stool can be seen in patients with gastric carcinoma and is often used as a screening tool in high-risk populations.

 

Option D. Highly radiosensitive tumor: Incorrect. Gastric adenocarcinoma is relatively radioresistant. While radiotherapy can be used for palliative purposes, it is not highly effective as a primary treatment due to the tumor's resistance and the potential for damage to adjacent tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastric carcinoma is often associated with hypochlorhydria or achlorhydria and can present with occult blood in the stool, but it is not a highly radiosensitive tumor.

questions.text: A patient presents with a lower limb wound as shown. The wound had healthy granulation tissue. What will be used as a cover? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Split thickness skin graft

 

The correct answer is Split thickness skin graft (STSG). STSG is the preferred choice for covering a large, healing wound with healthy granulation tissue, such as a burn or degloving injury. It involves taking a thin layer of skin from a donor site and applying it to the wound. This type of graft covers large areas and is effective in promoting wound healing with adequate tissue coverage while maintaining flexibility. It is generally used on body areas where cosmesis is less of a priority compared to the face, which would require a full thickness graft.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B.  Full thickness skin graft: This graft involves both the epidermis and the entire dermis and is typically used for areas requiring greater cosmetic outcomes, such as the face. It is not generally used for large wounds with healthy granulation tissue, as STSG would suffice and cover larger areas with a better healing outcome.

 

Option C.  VAC dressing: Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) dressing is used for non-healing or chronic wounds that require additional stimulation for granulation tissue formation and wound contraction. It is not needed when the wound already has healthy granulation tissue and is progressing well in healing.

 

Option D.  Flap: A flap is used when there is a need for bulk tissue to cover a deep or complex wound that involves structures like bone, tendons, or joints. Since the wound described has healthy granulation tissue and is not deep, a flap is unnecessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Split thickness skin grafts are the best choice for covering large, healthy granulating wounds, particularly in areas where cosmesis is not the primary concern.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male came with a history of progressive dysphagia, initially to solid foods and now to liquids too. He has also experienced significant weight loss over the past few months. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for diagnosing the underlying cause of his symptoms? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper GI Endoscopy 

 

The patient's symptoms of progressive dysphagia first to solids and then to liquids, along with significant weight loss, are concerning for an esophageal pathology, possibly a malignancy. 

 

This is the investigation of choice for evaluating dysphagia. It allows direct visualization of the esophageal lumen, can detect strictures, masses, or other abnormalities, and offers the possibility of biopsy, which is essential for diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endoscopic ultrasound: This can provide detailed images of the esophageal wall and adjacent structures and is useful for staging esophageal cancer. It is generally not the first test ordered when investigating dysphagia.

 

Option C. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT): While CECT can provide information about the extent of a disease and help in staging cancer, it is not the first-line investigation for dysphagia and cannot provide a definitive diagnosis without endoscopic visualization and biopsy.

 

Option D. Barium swallow: A barium swallow X-ray study can show structural changes in the esophagus, such as narrowing or obstruction, and is useful in diagnosing conditions like achalasia or strictures. However, it is less definitive than endoscopy for tissue diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Upper GI endoscopy is the first-line diagnostic tool for evaluating a patient with progressive dysphagia and significant weight loss, as it allows for direct visualization and biopsy to establish a definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presented with recurrent bilious vomiting. An X-ray erect abdomen is shown below. What is the next best step in managing this condition? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gastrograffin follow-through

 

The given clinical history along with the radiograph showing the triple bubble sign implies a diagnosis of jejunal atresia. A contrast study should be the next best investigation to exclude other large bowel anomalies.

 

A Gastrograffin follow-through is a radiological procedure that involves the administration of contrast material (Gastrograffin) followed by a series of X-rays to visualize the gastrointestinal tract. An alternate investigation would be CT with contrast (not given in options). In cases of recurrent bilious vomiting, it is a valuable diagnostic tool to assess for intestinal obstruction, such as malrotation or other anatomical abnormalities. It helps determine if there are any blockages or abnormalities in the intestines that may be causing the vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Upper GI endoscopy: Performing an endoscopy is generally not the first-line investigation for a neonate with recurrent bilious vomiting where an obstructive GI pathology is likely.

 

Option C. USG abdomen: An ultrasound (USG) of the abdomen can provide useful information in some cases, but it may not be the most appropriate initial investigation for recurrent bilious vomiting when there is a need to evaluate the entire gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option D. Explorative laparotomy: Explorative laparotomy, which involves surgery to explore the abdominal cavity, is a more invasive option and is typically considered when other diagnostic methods have failed to provide a clear diagnosis or when there is a strong suspicion of a surgical emergency. It is not the first-line choice in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Small bowel atresia’s present with intestinal obstruction soon after birth.

 

  • Bilious vomiting is the dominant feature in jejunal atresia
  • Abdominal distension is more prominent with ileal atresia.

 

A small amount of pale meconium may be passed despite the atresia.

 

Plain abdominal radiographs show a variable number of dilated loops of bowel and fluid levels according to the level of obstruction

 

In most cases of jejunal/ileal atresia, the distal end of the dilated proximal small bowel is resected and a primary end-to-end anastomosis is performed. If the proximal bowel is extremely dilated, it may need to be tapered to the distal bowel before anastomosis.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presented to the OPD with a scald injury on his arm. The lesion was pink, oozing, and painful to moving air and touch. Which of the following would be the most appropriate management? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Collagen dressing

 

Scald injury (damage due to contact with hot liquids) that appears pink in colour, has oozing, and pain is suggestive of a 2nd-degree superficial burn (i.e., partial-thickness burn). Collagen dressing is the most appropriate management for this injury.

 

Collagen dressings are an appropriate choice for partial-thickness burn wounds and scald injuries. They provide several advantages, including promoting wound healing, reducing pain, and helping to maintain a moist environment, which is conducive to tissue repair. Collagen dressings can be especially helpful in managing painful wounds like scald injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silver Sulphadiazine Cream Dressing: Silver sulfadiazine cream is commonly used for burn wounds. However, in the case of a scald injury like the one described (pink, oozing, and painful), silver sulfadiazine cream may not be the first choice. This cream is used for second degree deep and third degree burns.

 

Option B. Excision and Grafting: Excision and grafting are typically reserved for severe burn injuries that involve full-thickness damage to the skin and underlying tissues. In the case of a pink, oozing, and painful scald injury, which is likely partial-thickness, excision and grafting may be overly aggressive and not necessary.

 

Option C. Paraffin Gauze Dressing: Paraffin gauze dressings are often used for burn wounds. They provide a non-adherent surface and help maintain a moist wound environment. While this dressing may be suitable, collagen dressings (Option D) are better at promoting wound healing and tissue repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best dressing for burn wounds is skin; collagen is a good substitute for skin, especially in partial-thickness burns. For full-thickness burns, sequential excision and grafting must be considered.

 

Initial treatment for burns includes cleaning the burnt areas and removing loose dead skin. Blisters are de-roofed and an appropriate dressing is applied.

 

Biological dressing (collagen dressings, amniotic membrane, etc.) is the preferred dressing material, especially in partial thickness burns.

 

If this is not available then a non-adhesive dressing like paraffin gauze impregnated with silver sulfadiazine (SSD) cream, colloidal silver, ionic silver cream, or silver nitrate cream may be applied. Since increased resistance to SSD has recently emerged, it should be used judiciously and reserved for deep dermal, full thickness, infected, and old neglected burns.

questions.text: A lady presents with a three-day history of epigastric pain radiating to the back. Serum amylase levels were observed to be normal while USG abdomen reveals gall bladder stones and an enlarged pancreas. CT scan was done which clinched the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Acute Pancreatitis

 

Explanation:

 

Acute pancreatitis is characterized by epigastric pain that often radiates to the back. Although elevated serum amylase is commonly seen in acute pancreatitis, normal levels do not exclude the diagnosis. The presence of an enlarged pancreas on ultrasonography is suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Gallstones are a common cause of acute pancreatitis, and their presence in the gallbladder further supports this diagnosis. A contrast-enhanced CT scan is the definitive imaging modality for diagnosing acute pancreatitis, assessing its severity, and identifying complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute cholecystitis: While gallstones are present, the combination of pancreatic enlargement and radiating pain to the back is more indicative of acute pancreatitis than acute cholecystitis, which typically presents with right upper quadrant pain and tenderness.

 

Option C. Acute appendicitis: This condition presents with right lower quadrant pain and is not associated with pancreatic enlargement or gallstones.

 

Option D. Acute peritonitis: Peritonitis would present with diffuse abdominal pain and tenderness, not specifically epigastric pain radiating to the back, and would not be associated with pancreatic enlargement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute pancreatitis can present with normal serum amylase levels. The presence of epigastric pain radiating to the back, an enlarged pancreas on imaging, and gallstones strongly suggest acute pancreatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the least likely feature of high small bowel obstruction:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Distension

 

Explanation:

 

High small bowel obstruction is characterized by early and profuse vomiting, severe pain, and rapid dehydration. However, distension is minimal in high small bowel obstruction because the obstruction is proximal, allowing for only a small amount of fluid and gas accumulation before vomiting occurs. The primary features are as follows:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pain: Pain is a prominent feature in high small bowel obstruction.

 

Option C. Vomiting: Vomiting is early and profuse in high small bowel obstruction.

 

Option D. Dehydration: Dehydration occurs rapidly due to profuse vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Distension is minimal in high small bowel obstruction, making it the least likely feature compared to pain, vomiting, and dehydration.

questions.text: Identify the device used in surgery: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Verees needle

 

The device shown in the image is a Verees needle, which is commonly used for establishing pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries. The Verees needle is a spring-loaded needle with a blunt tip that retracts when it punctures the peritoneum, thereby reducing the risk of injury to internal organs. It is used to introduce carbon dioxide (CO2) gas into the peritoneal cavity, creating a working space for laparoscopic instruments.

 

CO2 is preferred for creating pneumoperitoneum because it is non-combustible and the risk of air embolism is low due to its rapid excretion from the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidural catheter:

 

 

Option C. Optical trocar:

 

 

Option D. Spinal needle:   

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Verees needle is a specialized instrument used to safely establish pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries by introducing CO2 into the peritoneal cavity.

questions.text: Mr. Thompson, a 58-year-old male, underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy for the treatment of gallstones. Following the procedure, he complained of abdominal pain and fever. Upon further evaluation, it was found that he had a bile leak. The surgeon ordered imaging tests to identify the extent of the bile duct injury. The imaging results showed injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct with bile leak. What would be the Strasberg classification of this injury? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type C

 

Injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct associated with bile leak is classified as Strasberg's type C injury.
