Correct. Strasberg Type C injuries are defined by bile leaks from the major ductal systems, such as the right posterior sectoral duct in this case. The leak can be caused by a missed stone, an unrecognized transection, or an avulsion due to excessive traction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type A: Strasberg Type A injuries are characterized by bile leaks from minor ducts or cystic duct that are present either at or near the gallbladder bed. They often present as bile collections in the gallbladder fossa.

 

Option B. Type B: Type B injuries involve an occlusion of the right posterior bile duct. This occlusion might be due to a clip placement or ligature, typically at the time of surgery. It does not involve a bile leak from an aberrant right posterior sectoral duct.

 

Option D. Type D: Type D injuries are characterized by lateral injury or partial transection of extrahepatic bile ducts/Common hepatic hepatic. This would be more extensive than just a leak from an aberrant duct.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Cervical spine stabilization, intubation, IV cannulation, CECT
Intubation, cervical spine stabilization, IV cannulation, CECT
IV cannulation, cervical spine stabilization, intubation, CECT
IV cannulation, intubation, CECT, cervical spine stabilization

questions.text: In a patient who presents to the casualty with an RTA, what is the correct sequence of management? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cervical spine stabilization, intubation, IV cannulation, CECT

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervical spine stabilization, intubation, IV cannulation, CECT is the correct sequence of management in a patient who presents to the casualty with an RTA.

 

The steps in Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) include the following: primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation, secondary survey, and definitive care.

 

The ABCDE of trauma care include Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate), Breathing and ventilation assessment, Circulation assessment, Disability assessment, and Exposure, with environmental control. During airway securing, cervical spine should be stabilised first (with a hard cervical collar) prior to attempting any manoeuvres like endotracheal intubation.

 

Adjuncts to the primary survey include blood tests, ECG, pulse oximetry, urinary and gastric catheters, and radiographs.

 

Specialized imaging like CECT should be considered after the secondary survey and only when the patient is stable after initial resuscitation.

questions.text: In a suspected case of cholangitis in a 47-year-old woman, what other component besides abdominal pain does not comprise Reynold's pentad? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hematemesis

 

Hematemesis (vomiting of blood) is not a component of Reynold's pentad. Reynold's pentad includes: jaundice, fever, abdominal pain, altered sensorium, and hypotension. Hematemesis can be a symptom of various other gastrointestinal issues but is not typically associated with cholangitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Cholangitis is an infection of the common bile duct caused by obstruction and increased pressure due to CBD stones.
  2. The classical triad of cholangitis (Charcot) is fever, right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice.
  3. If left untreated, cholangitis can progress to Reynold's pentad with hypotension and altered mental status due to sepsis.
  4. Abdominal ultrasound is used to diagnose biliary stones and bile duct dilatations in cholangitis.
  5. Treatment for cholangitis includes broad-spectrum antibiotics, rehydration, and biliary drainage using endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP).
  6. Biliary stones are the primary cause of cholangitis and can be removed by endoscopic sphincterotomy during ERCP.

choices.text: Shaving with razor night before operation

questions.text: Which of the following is the best method for hair removal to avoid surgical site infection? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hair clippers on table

 

The sequence of hair removal methods in terms of the least risk of infection is:

 

  • On-table clipping of hair > on-table use of depilatory creams > razor

 

Hair clippers on table:

 

  • Mechanism: Hair clippers trim hair close to the skin without causing micro-abrasions associated with shaving or chemical irritation from depilatory creams. The action is mechanical rather than chemical, minimizing skin irritation.
  • Timing: "On table" means that the hair removal is done immediately before the surgical procedure, leaving minimal time for any bacterial colonization, thus reducing the chances of infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shaving with a razor night before operation:

 

  • Risk: Shaving can create micro-abrasions (tiny cuts) in the skin, serving as potential entry points for bacteria. These small wounds might get infected, leading to surgical site infections.
  • Timing: Shaving the night before also provides time for bacteria to colonize these micro-abrasions, increasing the risk of infection.

 

Option B. Depilatory cream before operation:

 

  • Mechanism: Depilatory creams break down hair and do not create the same abrasions as razors.
  • Risk: They can cause skin irritation, potentially leading to a weakened skin barrier. A compromised skin barrier can increase the risk of bacterial invasion and infection.
  • Timing: Using it immediately before the surgery reduces the colonization time for bacteria, but there is still some risk due to potential skin irritation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best method for hair removal to avoid surgical site infection is using hair clippers immediately before the surgical procedure.

questions.text: During the insertion of a Ryle’s tube, what is the best position for a conscious patient to be in? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sitting with neck flexion

 

This is the best position for a conscious patient during Ryle's tube insertion. Sitting allows for better alignment of the upper gastrointestinal tract, making it easier to guide the tube through the esophagus and into the stomach. Neck flexion helps align the crico-pharynx with the Ryle’s tube, reducing faulty tracheal insertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of Ryle's tube is sitting with neck flexion.

 

Confirmation of the correct position of RT is done by:

 

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • Aspiration of gastric contents
  • X-ray chest + upper abdomen

 

The approximate length of the Ryle’s tube is 120-125 cm. There are 4 markings on the tube which indicates the traversing of the tube through various parts of the stomach

 

  1. 40 cm - Tube has traversed cardia of the stomach
  2. 50 cm - Tube has traversed body of the stomach
  3. 60 cm - Tube has traversed pylorus
  4. 70 cm - Tube has traversed duodenum

 

The length of tube to be inserted is calculated by measuring the distance between nose-tip of ear lobule-xiphoid (N-E-X rule).

questions.text: Which of these is not a feature of Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory rate > 22/ minute and PaCO2 <35mmHg

 

  • This statement does not align with the criteria for SIRS. In SIRS, an elevated respiratory rate (tachypnea) is defined as a respiratory rate greater than 20 breaths per minute or an arterial carbon dioxide partial pressure (PaCO2) less than 32 mmHg. Therefore, the option presented combines an elevated respiratory rate with an abnormally low PaCO2, which is not part of the SIRS criteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features of Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) are:

 

  • Fever (body temperature >38°C) or temperature <36°C.
  • Tachycardia (heart rate >90 beats per minute).
  • Tachypnea (respiratory rate >20 breaths per minute or arterial carbon dioxide tension (PaCO2) < 32 mm Hg).
  • Leukocytosis (white blood cell count >12,000 cells/mm³), leukopenia (white blood cell count <4,000 cells/mm³), or the presence of >10% immature neutrophils (band forms) in the blood.
  • Other signs of systemic inflammation such as elevated levels of C-reactive protein (CRP) or procalcitonin.

choices.text: Bag mask ventilation with jaw thrust

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department following severe maxillofacial trauma sustained in a road traffic accident. The airway is compromised, and immediate intervention is required. What is the most appropriate immediate management? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cricothyroidotomy 

 

Cricothyroidotomy involves making an incision through the cricothyroid membrane to establish an emergency airway. It's the most appropriate immediate management in cases of severe maxillofacial trauma with compromised airway when orotracheal intubation is not feasible or contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tracheostomy: Tracheostomy involves creating an opening in the trachea through the neck to establish an airway. While it's a definitive airway management technique, it's not the most appropriate immediate management in an emergency due to the time required and the need for specialized equipment.

 

Option B. Orotracheal intubation: Orotracheal intubation involves passing an endotracheal tube through the mouth into the trachea to secure the airway. It's a commonly performed procedure in emergency settings for airway management, but it may be challenging or contraindicated in cases of severe maxillofacial trauma.

 

Option D. Bag-mask ventilation with jaw thrust: Bag-mask ventilation involves manually delivering breaths using a bag and mask to ventilate the patient's lungs. While it can provide temporary oxygenation, it may not be sufficient for maintaining a patent airway in cases of severe maxillofacial trauma with compromised airway.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In cases of severe maxillofacial trauma with compromised airway, cricothyroidotomy is the most appropriate immediate management to establish an emergency airway when orotracheal intubation is not feasible or contraindicated.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented to the dermatologist with a small lesion on her right nasolabial fold. Upon examination, the dermatologist noted a 0.4-cm nodule with a smooth surface and well-defined borders. The nodule was located on the upper forehead, just above the eyebrows. It was excised and a pathological examination was done. The image is given below. What is the diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Basal cell carcinoma

  • The pathological report reveals basal cell carcinoma, a type of skin cancer that is commonly found on sun-exposed areas of the body.
  • Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer.
  • It arises from the basal cells, which are found at the bottom of the epidermis. BCCs are typically slow-growing tumors that rarely metastasize but can cause significant local destruction if left untreated.
  • They commonly appear as pearly nodules with visible blood vessels (telangiectasia), often with a central depression or ulceration.
  • They are commonly found in sun-exposed areas, which makes their presence on the face, especially the nasolabial fold, quite typical.
  • Mohs micrographic surgery is one of the most effective treatments for BCC, especially for tumors located in cosmetically sensitive areas, as it ensures complete removal while sparing the maximum amount of healthy tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanoma: Melanoma is a more aggressive form of skin cancer that arises from melanocytes, the cells responsible for producing skin pigment. Melanomas are characterized by their asymmetry, irregular borders, multiple colors, diameter greater than 6mm, and evolving size, shape, or color. They can develop from pre-existing moles or appear de novo. Early detection and treatment are crucial as melanoma has a higher potential for metastasis compared to other skin cancers.

 

Option C. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is also commonly found in sun-exposed areas and is associated with chronic sun damage. While it is less aggressive than melanoma, if left untreated, it can grow deeply and cause significant damage. In rare cases, it can also spread to other parts of the body. It shows keratin pearls on histopathology.

 

Option D. Nevus: A nevus, commonly known as a mole, is a benign growth on the skin that arises from melanocytes. Moles are usually brown or black and can be located anywhere on the body. They can be present at birth or appear during childhood and adolescence. While most moles are harmless, it is essential to monitor them for changes that might suggest a transformation into melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer and is typically found in sun-exposed areas.
  • It appears as a pearly nodule with visible blood vessels and can cause significant local destruction if left untreated.
  • Mohs micrographic surgery is an effective treatment, particularly for tumors in cosmetically sensitive areas.

choices.text: Encephalopathy, AST, albumin, bilirubin, Prothrombin time
Encephalopathy, ascites, albumin, bilirubin, prothrombin time

questions.text: Which of these are the components of Child Pugh score? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Encephalopathy, ascites, albumin, bilirubin, prothrombin time.

 

Encephalitis, ascites, albumin, bilirubin, Prothrombin time are the components of Child Pugh score

 

  • The Child-Pugh score is used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease and cirrhosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The components of the Child-Pugh score include encephalopathy, ascites, bilirubin, albumin, and prothrombin time (INR). This scoring system is used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease and cirrhosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male underwent surgery for rectal prolapse, and a postoperative image was obtained. Can you identify the procedure that was most likely performed on the patient from the given image below ? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thiersch stitch

 

  • The postoperative image suggests the use of Thiersch wiring for rectal prolapse.
  • Thiersch's wiring involves placing a steel wire or a silastic/nylon tape around the anal canal.
  • It is now rarely done due to postoperative problems such as chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stapled hemorrhoidopexy: A minimally invasive surgical technique used to treat internal hemorrhoids by repositioning prolapsed tissue back to its normal anatomical position with a circular stapling device. This procedure does not align with the provided image of Thiersch wiring.

 

Option B. Well's procedure: An abdominal procedure for rectal prolapse that involves repositioning and attaching the rectum to the sacrum using sutures, often reinforced with mesh. This technique does not correspond to the image provided, which clearly shows a perineal approach with wiring.

 

Option D. Altemeier repair: A perineal approach to resect and anastomose the prolapsed rectum. While Altemeier repair is a perineal procedure, it involves resection and anastomosis rather than the placement of a circumferential wire around the anus, as seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thiersch's procedure, involving the placement of a wire or tape around the anal canal, is used in managing rectal prolapse but is now infrequently performed due to associated complications such as chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation.

questions.text: Given the image showing significant limb swelling, which body system is likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lymphatics

 

The image shows significant swelling of the limb, particularly in the calf region, with a characteristic "tree trunk" appearance. This presentation is indicative of lymphedema, which is a condition resulting from impairment of the lymphatic system. The swelling, shape, and involvement of the foot and toes (squaring of toes) are classic features of lymphedema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Artery: Arterial involvement would typically cause limb wasting rather than swelling, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Vein: Venous involvement would present as varicose veins, which are not seen in the image, ruling out this option.

 

Option D. Muscle: Muscular involvement does not present in the characteristic way shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Significant limb swelling with a characteristic "tree trunk" appearance in the calf region, along with swelling of the foot and squaring of the toes, is a classic presentation of lymphedema, suggesting involvement of the lymphatic system.

questions.text: What is the optimal urine output for a patient who has undergone laparoscopic cholecystectomy? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.5-1.5 ml/kg/hour

 

After a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, it is anticipated that the patient will have a normal urine output during the postoperative phase, which is 0.5-1.5 ml/kg/hour.

 

If converted into ml/day, approximately 1500 ml/day in an avg. adult

 

If converted into ml/minute, approximately 1 to 1.5 ml/minute in an avg. adult

 

If converted into ml/kg, approximately 12-36 ml/day in an avg. adult

questions.text: Which of these is not an expected complication of Heller’s operation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gas bloat syndrome

 

  • The most common surgical procedure for achalasia is laparoscopic Heller myotomy, usually performed in conjunction with an anti-reflux procedure (partial fundoplication) to prevent post-operative acid reflux (option B). 
  • During the procedure, the anterior vagus nerve can be injured (option A). Forceful myotomy may also tear the mucosa and lead to perforation (Option D).
  • Gas bloat is seen after fundoplication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Injury to the vagus nerve: It can occur during dissection around the esophagus.

 

Option B. Acid reflux: It can occur especially if the myotomy is not combined with a partial fundoplication, since the LES is weakened.

 

Option D. Esophageal perforation: It can occur due to the delicate nature of the esophageal wall during the procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gas bloat syndrome is more commonly associated with Nissen fundoplication, a procedure for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
  • It occurs when patients are unable to burp, leading to bloating and discomfort from trapped gas.
  • Thus, gas bloat syndrome is not a complication of Heller’s myotomy.

choices.text: Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with Wilson's disease is being considered for liver transplantation. According to King's College Criteria for predicting mortality in Acute Liver Failure (ALF), which of the following is not included?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy

 

Explanation: 

 

King's College Criteria are widely used to predict mortality in patients with acute liver failure and identify those who may require urgent liver transplantation.

 

Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy: According to the King's College Criteria for non-paracetamol causes, a duration of jaundice before the onset of encephalopathy greater than 7 days (not less than 7 days) is one of the parameters that might indicate the need for liver transplantation. If the encephalopathy develops rapidly after the onset of jaundice (i.e., within 7 days), it suggests a more acute and potentially reversible cause, such as acute viral hepatitis, which might recover without transplantation.

 

Given the information, the incorrect parameter in the King's College criteria for transplantation, would be "Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy" (Option D).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age <10 years: Age is a factor in the King's College Criteria for non-paracetamol-induced liver failure. Children aged less than 10 years are considered at higher risk and this age group may be included in the criteria for transplantation.

 

Option B. PT >100s: Prothrombin time (PT) reflects the liver's ability to synthesize clotting factors. A greatly prolonged PT (>100 seconds) is an indication of severe liver dysfunction and is one of the King's College Criteria for both paracetamol and non-paracetamol-induced liver failure as a potential requirement for liver transplantation.

 

Option C. Bilirubin >300 µmol/L: An elevated bilirubin level indicates significant liver dysfunction. A bilirubin level greater than 300 µmol/L is one of the King's College Criteria for non-paracetamol-induced liver failure and suggests that liver transplantation may be necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

King's College Criteria for liver transplantation in acute liver failure include specific parameters such as prolonged PT, elevated bilirubin, and specific age groups. The duration of jaundice before the development of encephalopathy is significant if it exceeds 7 days. Jaundice for less than 7 days is not a parameter for transplantation.

choices.text: Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the ER after falling off a horse. Her vitals are stable, but she complains of pain and tenderness in her lower abdomen and has not passed urine yet. On examination, there is a visible bruise over her lower abdomen, and blood is seen at the urethral meatus. The bladder is not palpable. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy

 

The most appropriate initial management option for a patient with a possible bladder injury is Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy.

 

Trauma to lower abdomen with blood at urethral meatus implies urethral rupture. The most appropriate initial management option for a patient with a possible urethral injury is Wait for the bladder to fill and then do a suprapubic cystostomy.

 

After bladder fills up with urine, a suprapubic cystostomy is done in immediate management of urethral rupture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait and send her home: This option is not appropriate for a patient with a possible urethral injury.

 

Option B. Immediate insertion of Foley catheter: This option involves the insertion of a small tube through the urethra and into the bladder to drain urine. This is contraindicated in suspected urethral rupture, as it may create false passage.

 

Option C. Suprapubic aspiration of urine: This option involves inserting a needle through the skin and into the bladder to aspirate urine. This option may be preferred in cases where the urethra is injured or obstructed, making the insertion of a Foley catheter difficult. For this to be done, the bladder should be distended.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented with a noticeable swelling in his scrotum. After careful evaluation, a decision was made to perform an orchidectomy. The histopathological examination of the tissue reveals the following findings. Based on these findings which of the following diagnoses best describes the patient's condition? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Seminoma

 

  • Morphological - well-circumscribed, pale, gray-white, fleshy, homogenous mass, with a lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis.
  • Sheets of large, uniform, round or polygonal cells with clear cytoplasm and distinct cell borders.
  • Large central nuclei with prominent nucleoli.
  • Minimal mitotic activity and no or few infiltrating lymphocytes or Syncytiotrophoblast.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yolk-sac tumor:

  • Morphological - Yolk-sac tumor has a yellowish-white, mucinous appearance.
  • Microscopic features include Schiller-Duval bodies (central vessel surrounded by tumor cells), which resemble a yolk sac.
  • Tumor cells have clear to eosinophilic cytoplasm with small round nuclei and frequent mitotic figures.

 

Option C. Embryonal cell carcinoma:

  • Morphological - Embryonal cell carcinoma appears variegated with foci of hemorrhage or necrosis.
  • Composed of solid sheets or nests of primitive, undifferentiated cells.
  • Cells are variable in size and shape, with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio and frequent mitotic figures.

 

Option D. Teratoma:

  • Morphological - Teratomas also have a variegated appearance but have cysts reflecting the multiplicity of tissue types.
  • Composed of multiple germ layers, including ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm.
  • May contain a variety of tissues, including skin, hair, bone, cartilage, and neural tissue.
  • Immature teratomas may have undifferentiated, primitive neural or mesenchymal tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seminoma is a type of germ cell tumor characterized by large, uniform, polygonal cells with clear cytoplasm, distinct cell borders, and prominent central nucleoli, often presenting as a well-circumscribed, gray-white, fleshy mass without hemorrhage or necrosis.

questions.text: A patient suffered from an injury to right lower limb 3 days ago following which he was brought to hospital. The injury is as shown in the image. What would be the likely treatment in this patient? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Debridement & hyperbaric oxygen

 

The given image shows gangrenous patches of the skin spread throughout the lower limb, with patchy erythema, likely indicative of necrotizing fasciitis. Extensive debridement with hyperbaric oxygen to hasten healing is recommended. Primary closure should not be done in the presence of necrotic tissue.

 

Debridement & hyperbaric oxygen:

 

  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy: Increases the oxygen concentration in the blood, which can help wounds heal more quickly and fight certain types of infections.
  • Suitability: For necrotizing fasciitis, prompt and aggressive debridement is crucial. After debridement, hyperbaric oxygen can be beneficial. It can suppress the growth of anaerobic bacteria, enhance white blood cell function, and improve tissue oxygenation – all of which are beneficial in treating necrotizing fasciitis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Debridement & rotational advancement flap:

 

  • Debridement: Involves removing dead, damaged, or infected tissue to facilitate healing.
  • Rotational advancement flap: Involves moving nearby healthy skin and tissue to cover a wound.
  • Suitability: While debridement is crucial for necrotizing fasciitis, a rotational flap might not be the best immediate solution, especially if there's extensive tissue damage or ongoing infection. The primary focus should be on controlling the infection.

 

Option B. Debridement & primary closure:

 

  • Primary closure: Means directly suturing or closing the wound after debridement.
  • Suitability: In the case of necrotizing fasciitis, primary closure is not recommended initially. It's essential to ensure that all necrotic tissue is removed and the infection is under control before thinking about wound closure. Closing a wound with any lingering infection can lead to the infection being trapped and can worsen the patient's condition.

 

Option D. Amputation:

 

  • Amputation: Involves surgically removing a body part, typically an extremity.
  • Suitability: In some severe cases of necrotizing fasciitis, especially if the infection has rapidly progressed and threatens the patient's life, amputation might be a consideration. However, it's a last-resort treatment and would be considered only if other treatments fail and the limb is non-salvageable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For necrotizing fasciitis, the initial treatment should include extensive debridement and hyperbaric oxygen therapy to control the infection and promote healing.

It is due to hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles alone
Common metabolic condition seen is Hypokalemic alkalosis

questions.text: In Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) which of these would not be seen? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is due to hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles alone

 

Among the given options, the statement "C. It is due to hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles alone" is the one that would not be seen in a case of Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS).

 

Which makes it the right answer to the question asking which wouldn't be seen in IHPS. IHPS is caused by hypertrophy of the circular muscles of the pylorus, not the longitudinal muscles. This hypertrophy leads to an obstruction at the gastric outlet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It presents with non-bilious vomiting: This statement is correct. IHPS typically presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. This is because the pyloric stenosis obstructs the gastric outlet, but it is located before the bile duct entry into the duodenum. Therefore, vomitus will not contain bile.

 

Option B. USG is nearly 100% sensitive to detect IHPS: While ultrasonography (USG) is a highly sensitive and commonly used modality for the diagnosis of IHPS, stating that it is nearly "100% sensitive" may be an overstatement. However, for the purpose of the question, it is understood that USG is the preferred and very reliable method of diagnosis.

 

Option D. Common metabolic condition seen is Hypokalemic alkalosis: This statement is correct. Prolonged vomiting due to IHPS leads to the loss of gastric acid. This results in a metabolic alkalosis. The kidneys compensate for this by excreting more potassium in the urine, leading to hypokalemia. Hence, the condition termed "hypokalemic alkalosis" is a common metabolic disturbance in IHPS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) involves hypertrophy of the circular muscles of the pylorus, leading to gastric outlet obstruction and presenting with non-bilious vomiting. It is commonly diagnosed via highly sensitive ultrasonography, and the associated metabolic disturbance is hypokalemic alkalosis.
